It is noteworthy that, because of their dedicated spectrum resources, the transmit powers at $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and at $\mathrm{PU}_1$ are fixed and identical to each other (i.e., $P$ as used before) by using a certain power control strategy prior to data transmission \cite{KnoppICC95}. On the other hand, for the secondary user $\mathrm{SU}_1$, in order not to inflict harmful interference on nearby PUs, its transmit power (i.e., $P_{\mathrm{su}_1}$) must be dynamically allocated, which will be elaborated below.

If the noise variance is accounted for when computing the relay gain, \eqref{Eq.PowerAmplifier} can be rewritten as

It is noteworthy that, because of their dedicated spectrum resources, the transmit powers at $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and at $\mathrm{PU}_1$ are fixed and identical to each other (i.e., $P$ as used before) by using a certain power control strategy prior to data transmission \cite{KnoppICC95}. On the other hand, for the secondary user $\mathrm{SU}_1$, in order not to inflict harmful interference on nearby PUs, its transmit power (i.e., $P_{\mathrm{su}_1}$) must be dynamically allocated, which will be elaborated below.

Applying the Lagrangian optimization technique to (\ref{Eq.CapacityA})-(\ref{Eq.CapacityB}) in a similar way to \cite[Section 5.3.3]{Tse05}, it is easy to show that the optimal transmit power at $\mathrm{SU}_1$ is given by

{-\epsilon}|u|^{2}+r^{-\epsilon}|v|^{2}\right)}{l^{-\epsilon}|g|^{2}}\right]^{%
{\dagger}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><msub><mi>su</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></msub><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>q</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>u</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>v</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>l</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>†</mo></msup></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Like the well-known water-filling power allocation algorithm \cite{GoldsmithTIT97Nov}, the power allocation parameter $\lambda$ associated with \eqref{Eq.CapacityD} corresponds to the so-called water-level and it will be explicitly determined in the next subsection. The ceiling operator $[x]^{\dag}$ in (\ref{Eq.CapacityD}) implies that the transmit power is zero if the gain of the desired channel is smaller than or equal to a lower bound, i.e., $l^{-\epsilon}|g|^2 \le \frac{P}{\lambda}\left(q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2\right)d^{-\epsilon}|f|^2$. In such a case, no data will be transmitted at the SU. This makes the two-way relaying in spectrum-sharing context completely different from and, in particular, more energy-efficient than conventional two-way relaying, where the transmission between two nodes is irrespective of the channel fluctuations in between. Moreover, it is observed that the aforementioned lower bound is determined by the product of the gain of the interfering channel, i.e., $d^{-\epsilon}|f|^2$ and the strength of the CCI, i.e., $q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2$, which means that the impacts of the constraint on the tolerable interference power imposed by PUs and of the CCI coming from concurrent primary transmission, on the optimal power allocation at the SU are exchangeable.

Notice that, for two-way relaying without spectrum-sharing, the optimal power allocation in terms of maximizing the sum rate is equivalent to that of minimizing the outage probability \cite{XuTVT14}. However, in the context of spectrum-sharing, i.e., when the transmit power of SUs is strictly limited by the tolerable interference power dictated by PUs, as shown in \eqref{Eq.CapacityB}, more research efforts are needed to check the effectiveness of the aforementioned equivalence, which is beyond the scope of the paper.

{\bf Remark 2 (On the availability of channel state information (CSI) needed when performing power allocation at $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{SU}_1}$)}:
It is noteworthy that the channel parameters $(d, f)$, corresponding to the interfering channel from $\mathrm{SU}_1$ to $\mathrm{BS}_2$ as shown in Fig. \ref{Fig.SystemModel}, can be obtained at $\mathrm{SU}_1$ through periodic sounding of pilot signals transmitted by $\mathrm{BS}_2$. The channel parameters $(q, u)$ from $\mathrm{PU}_4$ to $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and $(r, v)$ from $\mathrm{PU}_4$ to $\mathrm{PU}_1$ can be obtained at $\mathrm{SU}_1$ through the feedback from $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and $\mathrm{PU}_1$, respectively. Although the acquisition of these CSI requires additional cost at $\mathrm{SU}_1$, it enables $\mathrm{SU}_1$ to strictly comply with the interference power constraint dictated by PUs and to maximize its achievable data rate.

{\bf Remark 3 (Constraints on the transmit power of SUs)}:
In CR systems, the tolerable interference power at PUs can be generally defined by means of average interference power or peak interference power or both \cite{MusavianTWC09Jan}. The average interference power constraint for SUs applies to non-real time applications and has low feedback overhead. The peak interference power constraint for SUs is suitable for real-time applications and has high feedback overhead. Also, there is a maximum output-power constraint for SUs in practice, i.e., a physically allowable maximum transmit power. Its effect on system performance is essentially equivalent to peak interference power constraint mentioned earlier. Nevertheless, it is demonstrated that ``imposing a constraint on the peak interference power does not yield a significant impact on the ergodic capacity as long as the average interference power is constrained'' \cite{MusavianTWC09Jan}. Hence, only the average interference power constraint is considered in the optimization problem formulated in \eqref{Eq.CapacityA}-\eqref{Eq.CapacityB}. For more detailed comparison between average and peak interference power constraints, the interested reader is referred to \cite{Zhang09TWC04}.


\subsection{Optimal Transmit Power at the SU}
\label{Subsection:PowerAllocation}
Now, we explicitly derive the value of the power-allocation parameter $\lambda$ in \eqref{Eq.CapacityD} and, then, it is applied to \eqref{Eq.CapacityC} to determine the optimal transmit power at $\mathrm{SU}_1$. To this end, we define a new random variable $T \triangleq \left(q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2\right)\frac{|f|^2}{|g|^2} = V_1V_3$, where $V_1 \triangleq |f|^2/|g|^2$ and $V_3 \triangleq q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2$. By recalling that the multi-path fading components of all channels in the considered system are supposed to be subject to Rayleigh fading, the PDFs of $|f|^2$ and $|g|^2$ are of the same exponential distribution:

The ceiling operator $[x]^{\dag}$ in (\ref{Eq.CapacityD}) implies that the transmit power is zero if the gain of the desired channel is smaller than or equal to a lower bound, i.e., $l^{-\epsilon}|g|^2 \le \frac{P}{\lambda}\left(q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2\right)d^{-\epsilon}|f|^2$. In such a case, no data will be transmitted at the SU. This makes the two-way relaying in spectrum-sharing context completely different from and, in particular, more energy-efficient than conventional two-way relaying, where the transmission between two nodes is irrespective of the channel fluctuations in between. Moreover, it is observed that the aforementioned lower bound is determined by the product of the gain of the interfering channel, i.e., $d^{-\epsilon}|f|^2$ and the strength of the CCI, i.e., $q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2$, which means that the impacts of the constraint on the tolerable interference power imposed by PUs and of the CCI coming from concurrent primary transmission, on the optimal power allocation at the SU are exchangeable.

Notice that, for two-way relaying without spectrum-sharing, the optimal power allocation in terms of maximizing the sum rate is equivalent to that of minimizing the outage probability \cite{XuTVT14}. However, in the context of spectrum-sharing, i.e., when the transmit power of SUs is strictly limited by the tolerable interference power dictated by PUs, as shown in \eqref{Eq.CapacityB}, more research efforts are needed to check the effectiveness of the aforementioned equivalence, which is beyond the scope of the paper.

{\bf Remark 2 (On the availability of channel state information (CSI) needed when performing power allocation at $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{SU}_1}$)}:
It is noteworthy that the channel parameters $(d, f)$, corresponding to the interfering channel from $\mathrm{SU}_1$ to $\mathrm{BS}_2$ as shown in Fig. \ref{Fig.SystemModel}, can be obtained at $\mathrm{SU}_1$ through periodic sounding of pilot signals transmitted by $\mathrm{BS}_2$. The channel parameters $(q, u)$ from $\mathrm{PU}_4$ to $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and $(r, v)$ from $\mathrm{PU}_4$ to $\mathrm{PU}_1$ can be obtained at $\mathrm{SU}_1$ through the feedback from $\mathrm{BS}_1$ and $\mathrm{PU}_1$, respectively. {\bf Remark 3 (Constraints on the transmit power of SUs)}:
In CR systems, the tolerable interference power at PUs can be generally defined by means of average interference power or peak interference power or both \cite{MusavianTWC09Jan}. The average interference power constraint for SUs applies to non-real time applications and has low feedback overhead. The peak interference power constraint for SUs is suitable for real-time applications and has high feedback overhead. Also, there is a maximum output-power constraint for SUs in practice, i.e., a physically allowable maximum transmit power. Its effect on system performance is essentially equivalent to peak interference power constraint mentioned earlier. Nevertheless, it is demonstrated that ``imposing a constraint on the peak interference power does not yield a significant impact on the ergodic capacity as long as the average interference power is constrained'' \cite{MusavianTWC09Jan}. Hence, only the average interference power constraint is considered in the optimization problem formulated in \eqref{Eq.CapacityA}-\eqref{Eq.CapacityB}. For more detailed comparison between average and peak interference power constraints, the interested reader is referred to \cite{Zhang09TWC04}.


\subsection{Optimal Transmit Power at the SU}
\label{Subsection:PowerAllocation}
Now, we explicitly derive the value of the power-allocation parameter $\lambda$ in \eqref{Eq.CapacityD} and, then, it is applied to \eqref{Eq.CapacityC} to determine the optimal transmit power at $\mathrm{SU}_1$. To this end, we define a new random variable $T \triangleq \left(q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2\right)\frac{|f|^2}{|g|^2} = V_1V_3$, where $V_1 \triangleq |f|^2/|g|^2$ and $V_3 \triangleq q^{-\epsilon}|u|^2 + r^{-\epsilon}|v|^2$. By recalling that the multi-path fading components of all channels in the considered system are supposed to be subject to Rayleigh fading, the PDFs of $|f|^2$ and $|g|^2$ are of the same exponential distribution:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f_{V_{3}}(x)=\begin{cases}c_{1}\left(e^{-q^{\epsilon}x}-e^{-r^{\epsilon}x}%
\right),&\text{if }q\neq r;\\
\frac{x}{q^{2\epsilon}}\,e^{-\frac{x}{q^{\epsilon}}},&\text{if }q=r,\end{cases}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow><mo>≠</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow><mo>;</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mstyle displaystyle="false"><mfrac><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></msup></mfrac></mstyle></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>x</mi><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup></mfrac></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mtext>if </mtext><mo>⁢</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $G[\,x\, \vert\,.\,]$ denotes the Meijer's $G$-function \cite[Eq.(16.17.1)]{NIST10}, and \cite[vol.1, Eq.(2.3.6.9)]{Prudnikov86} was exploited to reach \eqref{Eq.CDFT-2} and \cite[vol.3, Eq.(8.4.46.1)]{Prudnikov86} was used to attain \eqref{Eq.CDFT}. Moreover, in light of \cite[vol.3, Eq.(8.2.2.32)]{Prudnikov86} and by taking the derivative of \eqref{Eq.CDFT} with respect to $x$, we obtain the PDF of $T$, given by
prevtext:
where $c_1 \triangleq 1/\left(q^{-\epsilon}-r^{-\epsilon}\right)$. In practical cellular communication systems, the distance parameters $q$ and $r$ are generally unequal to each other (cf. Fig.~\ref{Fig.SystemModel}) and, thus, in the following we concentrate on the upper case of \eqref{Eq.PDFV3}. If the lower case with $q = r$ in \eqref{Eq.PDFV3} is to be considered, it can be analyzed in a similar way.

Specifically, by virtue of \eqref{Eq.PDFV} and \eqref{Eq.PDFV3}, the CDF of $T$ can be derived as follows.
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle F_{T}(x)" display="inline"><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{\infty}{F_{V_{1}}\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)f_{V_{3}}(y)}%
\,\mathrm{d}y" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><msub><mi>F</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>d</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=c_{1}\int_{0}^{\infty}{\frac{x}{x+y}\left(e^{-q^{\epsilon}y}-e^{%
-r^{\epsilon}y}\right)}\,\mathrm{d}y" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>d</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=c_{1}x\left[\Psi\left(1,\,1,\,q^{\epsilon}x\right)-\Psi\left(1,%
\,1,\,r^{\epsilon}x\right)\right]" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 1</mn><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 1</mn><mo rspace="4.2pt">,</mo><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\frac{c_{1}}{q^{\epsilon}}G_{1,\,2}^{2,\,1}\left[q^{\epsilon}x%
\left|\begin{gathered}\displaystyle 1\\
\displaystyle 1,1\end{gathered}\right.\right]-\frac{c_{1}}{r^{\epsilon}}G_{1,%
\,2}^{2,\,1}\left[r^{\epsilon}x\left|\begin{gathered}\displaystyle 1\\
\displaystyle 1,1\end{gathered}\right.\right]," display="inline"><mrow><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup></mfrac></mstyle><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mtable rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup></mfrac></mstyle><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 1</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mtable rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mn>1</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $G[\,x\, \vert\,.\,]$ denotes the Meijer's $G$-function \cite[Eq.(16.17.1)]{NIST10}, and \cite[vol.1, Eq.(2.3.6.9)]{Prudnikov86} was exploited to reach \eqref{Eq.CDFT-2} and \cite[vol.3, Eq.(8.4.46.1)]{Prudnikov86} was used to attain \eqref{Eq.CDFT}. Moreover, in light of \cite[vol.3, Eq.(8.2.2.32)]{Prudnikov86} and by taking the derivative of \eqref{Eq.CDFT} with respect to $x$, we obtain the PDF of $T$, given by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="f_{T}(x)=\frac{c_{1}}{x\,q^{\epsilon}}G_{2,\,3}^{2,\,2}\left[q^{\epsilon}x%

\displaystyle 1,1,1\end{gathered}\right.\right]-\frac{c_{1}}{x\,r^{\epsilon}}G%

\displaystyle 1,1,1\end{gathered}\right.\right]." display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup></mrow></mfrac><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mi>q</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>c</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup></mrow></mfrac><msubsup><mi>G</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn> 2</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></msup><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="center"><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: Subsequently, in light of  \eqref{Eq.CapacityD} and \eqref{Eq.PDFT}, the power-allocation parameter $\lambda$ can be determined by
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle 10^{\frac{W}{10}}" display="inline"><msup><mn>10</mn><mfrac><mi>W</mi><mn>10</mn></mfrac></msup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{\frac{\lambda}{\eta_{4}\bar{\gamma}P}}\left(\lambda-{%
\eta_{4}}Px\right)f_{T}(x)\,\mathrm{d}x" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi></mrow></mfrac></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>d</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E21.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle=\lambda F_{T}\left(\frac{\lambda}{\eta_{4}\bar{\gamma}P}\right)-%
{\eta_{4}}P\int_{0}^{\frac{\lambda}{\eta_{4}\bar{\gamma}P}}xf_{T}(x)\,\mathrm{%
d}x," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><mrow><msub><mi>η</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mi>P</mi></mrow></mfrac></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>T</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>d</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>
